truth: You write code faster than you read it.
Most bugs come from assumptions, not syntax.
Meetings often replace actual work.
Deadlines make you cut corners.
Tests are written after the code breaks.
Code reviews find your mistakes, not theirs.
You fix the same bug multiple times.
Documentation is always outdated.
Refactoring feels good but breaks things.
You ignore warnings until they become errors.
Code comments explain the obvious.
You learn more from failures than successes.
Simple solutions are often overlooked.
Time estimates are always wrong.
You write code you don't understand.
The person who talks the most about productivity is avoiding work.
The urgent task is rarely the important one.
Most decisions are made before the meeting starts.
The plan only works until reality shows up.
Someone will always suggest rewriting everything.
The clearer your explanation, the less people listen.
The person who assigns the task will never do it.
The bigger the launch, the smaller the testing window.
You will debug something you didn't change.
Most problems are discovered by users, not systems.
The process exists because something broke once.
The fastest way to delay work is to optimize it.
Someone will ask for changes after approval.
The simplest explanation is usually ignored first.
Every shortcut adds a future meeting.
The person who wants it fastest will review it slowest.
Work expands to fill the deadline.
The issue you can't explain is the one you caused.
The longer the thread, the less anyone reads it.
The system behaves exactly as it was built, not as intended.
If everyone agrees immediately, someone misunderstood.
The more slides there are, the less clarity there is.
Most urgency is manufactured.
You will fix something that was not broken.
The person most confident is usually guessing.
The real bottleneck is usually approval.
The feature request describes a symptom, not the problem.
The more stakeholders, the slower the truth.
Someone will propose a solution before hearing the problem.
You will understand the issue right after explaining it.
Every tool promises simplicity and delivers configuration.
The system that cannot fail is already failing quietly.
Someone will ask for metrics no one plans to read.
The explanation that makes sense is the one people doubt.
The more approvals required, the less ownership exists.
The problem marked minor becomes critical.
Someone will test it in a way you never imagined.
The system is only stable because nobody touched it.
The person who wrote it is no longer here.
Every roadmap is optimistic fiction.
The more planning there is, the less clarity remains.
The real issue is always discovered last.
You will fix it after someone watches you fail.
The person who said it was easy has never done it.
The task that looks small hides the most dependencies.
The more documentation exists, the less it is trusted.
The fastest solution creates the slowest maintenance.
Someone will blame the system before reading it.
The last change is always suspected first.
You will eventually understand code you once feared.
